FeedItems.Title: Introducing Search By Target Framework on NuGet.org
FeedItems.Summary:
Last year, we brought a new feature to improve the way you assess target framework compatibility of a NuGet package through a new “Frameworks” tab.
Today, we are announcing a new feature...

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: Change Target Framework Badges to be Latest instead of Lowest." (#9794) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Related Problem

_No response_

### The Elevator Pitch

When we started this work for Framework badges we had a decision to make of whether to do something familiar for package users in terms of providing them the lowest framework asset in the package or the highest.

We initially went with the lowest framework asset as that was the common practice with .NET & NuGet and would adjust based on feedback.

Now with further feedback, I believe we should re-consider this to be the latest asset to show how up-to-date the package actually is as it may make more sense long term for a consumer to see a package continues to provide support for the latest version of .NET.

**TL;DR - Display the latest TFM included rather than the lowest.**

Related and can be ignored if we do this work instead: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/9044

### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Parameterize Framework Badges front end code using helpers" (#9793) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: We can use a helper method to make the code in https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/blob/main/src/NuGetGallery/Views/Packages/_SupportedFrameworksBadges.cshtml more concise.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Make DateTime ISO 8601 throughout NuGet.org" (#9792) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/blob/7f55d930b98e3fcd0d901bb897819d96a9ebedb8/src/NuGetGallery.Services/Extensions/DateTimeExtensions.cs#L21C9-L24C10 -> ``` public static string ToNuGetShortDateString(this DateTime self) { return self.ToString("yyyy-MM-dd"); } ``` Or similar?

### Impact

Other

### Describe the bug

Statistics on the search page don't match statistics on the package details page.

### Repro Steps

Search for Fabulous Scheduler on NuGet.org and view the results: https://www.nuget.org/packages?q=fabulous+scheduler
Click on the FabulousScheduler link on the results page and view the stats on the package details page: https://www.nuget.org/packages/FabulousScheduler

They don't match.

### Expected Behavior

Both screen show the same download count.

### Screenshots

Search results:
![image](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/assets/14225979/b4367bef-acd3-48a0-9c9b-d7ff714aeb7e)

Package details:
![image](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/assets/14225979/08dccb02-94a8-4f06-963d-cc593b4b31f0)


### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: Search filters panel blinks when we click 'Apply'" (#9790) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Describe the bug

The checkboxes for the framework generations and TFMs blink when the search page is loaded with filter parameters. 

The likely cause for it how we initialize checobox states on the page. JavaScript code reads the search page URL and uses it to set the state of the checkboxes on the page. This happens after page load, which is why we see the blinking.

### Repro Steps

1. Select a framework generation or TFM filter checkbox, say `.NET`
2. Click on `Apply`
3. The `.NET` checkbox will blink after the page loads

### Expected Behavior

The checkbox states should be set in the `.cshtml` itself so that we don't need to run any JavaScript.

We can modify the `FrameworkFilterGroup` objects in the view model to have a checkbox state enum with `Checked/Unchecked/Indeterminate` values.

### Screenshots

_No response_

### Additional Context and logs

See https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/9782#issuecomment-1907354318

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: The primary search feed for api.nuget.org may be staying." (#9789) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Describe the bug

The primary SearchQueryService and secondary SearchQueryService presented in the following feeds return different numbers of downloads.
The primary SearchQueryService appears to be lagging behind.
https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json

I do not know if this is the planned behavior.


### Repro Steps

I compared the following two results (usnc and ussc)

- Primary SearchQueryService
    - https://azuresearch-usnc.nuget.org/query?q=packageid:System.Data.SQLite.Core
- Secondary SearchQueryService
    - https://azuresearch-ussc.nuget.org/query?q=packageid:System.Data.SQLite.Core

The following web page display is close to the secondary

- Web page
    - https://www.nuget.org/packages/System.Data.SQLite.Core


### Expected Behavior

If this is the response for the intended reason, then this is not a particular problem.
I created this issue because I had a question about the fact that the primary appears to return old results.


### Screenshots

_No response_

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: Number of downloads changes among web and mobile." (#9784) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Describe the bug

On last view, I realized number of downloads don't change on web view and I was suspecting if there is a problem through data. Then I checked, new versions of packages' download count and check mobile view to see same result. Interestingly, mobile view show correct number of downloads while web view doesn't.

### Repro Steps

1. Open URL on web view. https://www.nuget.org/profiles/Okullu
2. Open URL on mobile view. https://www.nuget.org/profiles/Okullu

### Expected Behavior

Same number of downloads on both usage of same web site.

### Screenshots

Mobile view:
![photo_2024-01-23_17-36-22](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/assets/4971757/cd22f130-df9e-410c-b74a-ad176073bbd1)

Web view: 
![image](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/assets/4971757/f30d0759-dee5-4b32-ac6e-f86a48ee1a07)



### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "LibraryDependency creates a collection that is mostly empty" (#13184) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe, MSBuild.exe

### Product Version

All

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

None

### Repro Steps & Context

The `LibraryDependency` creates a list for warnings but in a lot of code paths it ends up being empty so there's no need to allocate the list and instead it could be an empty singleton.

https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/a6fff16af6f44927a83851448a99beb1d2801600/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.LibraryModel/LibraryDependency.cs#L22

Originally reported internally: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1826369



### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature] Enable Transitive Dependencies for Solution-level in Visual Studio" (#13216) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### The Elevator Pitch

People love using the new transitive dependencies feature in Visual Studio for their projects! 

https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/introducing-transitive-dependencies-in-visual-studio/

One common follow-up is that people would love to see this experience in the solution-level within Visual Studio.

As we know from survey data, people use projects / solution levels just about equally and we originally went with projects to experiment with this feature as it has not been done before in Visual Studio.

This issue tracks bringing this experience to the solution-level in Visual Studio.

Please üëç or üëé this comment to help us with the direction of this feature & leave as much feedback/questions/concerns as you'd like on this issue itself and we will get back to you shortly.

Thank You üéâ

### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "FabricBot: Onboarding to GitOps.ResourceManagement because of FabricBot decommissioning" (#13215) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Add prIssueManagement.yml to onboard repo to GitOps.ResourceManagement as FabricBot replacement

 Details on the replacement service and the syntax of the new yaml configuration file is available publicly at: https://microsoft.github.io/GitOps/policies/resource-management.html

Please review and merge this PR to complete the process of onboarding to the new service.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "SetCentralDependencies is calling OrderBy without specifying comparison defaulting to cultural-sensitive compare" (#13182) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe, MSBuild.exe, NuGet.exe, Visual Studio Package Management UI, Visual Studio Package Manager Console

### Product Version

All

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

The `SetCentralDependencies` method writes the PackageVersion items to the `project.assets.json`.  It sorts the list but doesn't specify a string comparer which defaults to a culture-sensitive comparer.  This leads to wasted CPU time.  Instead, it should specify `StringComparer.OrdinalIgnoreCase` since the list is already de-duplicated.

https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/dev/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.ProjectModel/PackageSpecWriter.cs#L666

Originally reported internally: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1926308

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "PackageSpecWriter should write out original string for versions instead of allocating a new one" (#13183) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

MSBuild.exe, dotnet.exe

### Product Version

All

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

None

### Repro Steps & Context

The `SetCentralDependencies` method writes out the PackageVersion items to the `project.assets.json` and uses the normalized version.  This section is only read by our reader which parses it again during read so there's no need to allocate another string and instead should just write out the original string.

https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/dev/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.ProjectModel/PackageSpecWriter.cs#L668

Originally reported internally: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1828422

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "ProjectModel.HashObjectWriter.OnFlush is using a SHA512 hash versus a cheaper hash which seems like overkill" (#13214) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Affected

MSBuild.exe, dotnet.exe

### Current Behavior

Originally filed by the VS Perf team.  The `ProjectModel.HashObjectWriter` currently uses a SHA512 hash algorithm and we're wondering if a faster hash algorithm would still work and speed things up.

### Desired Behavior

A faster hashing algorithm that still yields the same outcome.

### Additional Context

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "PackageSpecWriter is calling Any on an ICollection<T>/IList<T> instances instead of .Count" (#13213) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

MSBuild.exe, NuGet.exe

### Product Version

All

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

None

### Repro Steps & Context

The `PackageSpecWriter` class calls the `.Any()` method on some `IList<T>` objects which causes allocations.  These should be avoided on hot paths.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "REST updates to licenses from licenses.nuget.org" (#13212) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

NuGet.exe, NuGet SDK, Other/NA

### The Elevator Pitch

Licenses such as MIT when served from https://licenses.nuget.org/MIT contain text like
```
MIT License
Copyright (c) <year> <copyright holders>
...
```
It would be really nice if place holder fields it the various licenses could be replaced at retrieval time with replacements that we quite possibly already know from the package or could be added with new metadata attributes/fields.

For example, a request could be made to https://licenses.nuget.org/MIT?year=2022&owner=Ty%20Coon,%20President%20of%20Vice
The license could be updated on the fly to return
```
MIT License
Copyright (c) 2022 Ty Coon, President of Vice
...
```


### Additional Context and Details

For a more lengthy example if we look at a license such as https://licenses.nuget.org/CPAL-1.0
How can we attribute the code properly if there fields are left empty?
For cases like this license I would think there's a case that having an embedded license (`<license type="file">`) is mandatory. But I'm sure this could be coded around, though much harder that the MIT license case.

If the package metadata contained.
<license type="expression">CPAL-1.0 OR MIT</license>
Admittedly that would be an odd combination but lets play with it for a moment...
`nuget pack` could query the [URL](https://https://licenses.nuget.org/CPAL-1.0?year=2024,author=Bob%20Loblaw,alternateLicense=MIT,contributors=John%20Doe,%20Jane%20Doe,%20Max%20Headroom) and save the license in the package as License.txt and add the `<license type="file">License.txt</license>`
Embedding the license file is particularly useful when using the package in an offline/standalone environment which doesn't have access to the internet. In these environments the expressions are 100% useless since the license can't be retrieved for viewing and/or inclusion in product release notes as required by some licenses.

To make the process of building the URLs easier it might be advantageous to add some new metadata fields/attributes to the `<license />`
examples of items that I think could be useful
- **year** attribute - example: `<license type="expression" year="2008-2024">MIT</license>` could be used in building the URL `https://https://licenses.nuget.org/MIT?year=**<The value of the year attribute>**`
- **owner** attribute - example: `<license type="expression" owner="ACME Inc">CPAL-1.0</license>` could be used in building the URL `https://https://licenses.nuget.org/CPAL-1.0?owner=**<The value of the owner attribute>**`
- **<contributors><contributor></contributor></contributors>** elements - example 
  ```
  <metadata>
  ...
  <contributors>
    <contributor>John Doe</contributor>
    <contributor>Jane Doe</contributor>
    <contributor>Max Headroom</contributor>
  </contributors>
  ...
  </metadata>
```
 could be used in building the URL `https://https://licenses.nuget.org/CPAL-1.0?contributors=**<The value all contributors joined>**`

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Read auditSources from nuget.config files" (#13211) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

NuGet SDK

### The Elevator Pitch

The first step for being able to use NuGetAudit without adding nuget.org as a package source, is to add `<auditSources>` to the nuget.config file, as specified in the feature spec: https://github.com/NuGet/Home/blob/dev/accepted/2023/NuGetAudit-without-nuget.org-as-packageSource.md

The work for this issue is to add APIs to NuGet.Configuration to be able to read the sources from nuget.config files. 

### Additional Context and Details

When this issue is complete, it does not mean that NuGetAudit, as part of restore, will use these sources yet. See this issue for the complete work:
* https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/12698
